title: 114_hr4943
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tribal Tax and Investment Reform Act of 2016". The Congress recognizes the unique legal and political relationship between the United States and Indian tribes, acknowledging tribes' authority to provide governmental programs, develop economies, and maintain infrastructure on reservation lands. Federal laws and regulations affirm tribes as governments with the authority to tax, issue bonds, and receive tax exemptions. Indian tribes have the inherent authority to tax, issue government bonds, and maintain tax exemptions. Tax parity for tribal governments aligns with Federal treaties recognizing tribal sovereignty. Tribes face historic disadvantages in accessing capital for infrastructure and governance development. Indian tribes face historic disadvantages in accessing capital for infrastructure and governance development. Certain statutory restrictions on tribal governance inhibit tribes' ability to develop strong economies. Tribes are sometimes excluded from key provisions in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, resulting in unfair tax treatment. Congress exercises its authority to regulate commerce with Indian tribes to further tribal self-governance and affirm the government-to-government relationship. Indian tribes are treated as states with respect to bond issuance. Indian tribal governments are treated as states for certain purposes under the Internal Revenue Code. Special rules for tax-exempt bonds issued by Indian tribal governments are established annually by the Secretary of the Treasury based on national tribal population estimates and minimum State ceiling amounts. The Internal Revenue Code establishes special rules for tax-exempt bonds issued by Indian tribal governments based on national tribal population estimates and minimum State ceiling amounts. The amendment repeals certain requirements and applies to obligations issued in calendar years after the enactment of the Act. The amendment repeals certain requirements for tax-exempt bonds issued by Indian tribal governments and applies to obligations issued in calendar years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Treatment of pension and employee benefit plans maintained by tribal governments. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include expanding the definition of qualified public safety employee to include Indian tribes and updating the definition of governmental plan to include plans established by Indian tribal governments. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is being amended to include Indian tribal governments in the definition of governmental plans and expanding the definition of qualified public safety employee to include Indian tribes. Plans established before the enactment date by Indian tribal governments or related entities will be treated as if established by an eligible employer. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 are also being made. Amendments are being made to include Indian tribal governments in the definition of governmental plans under Federal, State, or tribal law. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is referenced for the definition of Indian tribal government entities eligible for employee benefits. The amendment includes Indian tribal governments in the definition of governmental plans under Federal, State, or tribal law. Plans established by Indian tribal governments will be treated as if established by an eligible employer, as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment includes Indian tribal governments in the definition of governmental plans under Federal, State, or tribal law, treating them as if established by an eligible employer as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. Tribal foundations and charities treated like charities funded and controlled by governmental funders and sponsors. Section 170(b)(1)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include Indian tribal governments as governmental units. Section 509(a) is also amended to include Indian tribal governments for certain supporting organizations. The amendments made by this section include Indian tribal governments as governmental units for tax purposes, effective for taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. IMPROVING TRIBAL CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES' ACCESS TO FEDERAL SERVICES. Improving tribal child support enforcement agencies' access to federal services by amending the Social Security Act to include Indian tribes and tribal organizations eligible for grants under specific sections. Additionally, enhancing the collection of past-due child support from federal tax refunds for these entities. Amendment to the Social Security Act and Internal Revenue Code allows Indian tribes and tribal organizations eligible for grants to access federal services and collect past-due child support from tax refunds. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code recognizes Indian tribal governments for determining special needs in the adoption credit. Effective for taxable years after enactment of the Act.
